title: Two-GPU Local AI Architecture
description:
**NOTE**: This epic has been superseded by **home-server-hoh: Provider/Model Architecture Overhaul** which includes a more comprehensive design with provider/model separation, concurrency control, health checking, and agent support.

---

Original description:

Upgrade local AI infrastructure from single Windows-only inference to dual-GPU architecture.

## Architecture
- **RTX 3070 (Debian Server)**: Always-on control plane + small models (7B-8B)
- **RTX 3090 (Windows Gaming PC)**: Warm burst compute + big models (32B), gaming-gated

## Key Features
- Intelligent routing (small vs big requests)
- Gaming-aware gating (NORMAL/GAMING modes)
- Force-big override signals
- Fail-soft to 3070 if 3090 unavailable

## Core Principles
1. Gaming and LLM inference are incompatible when sharing GPU
2. Stability and determinism beat utilization
3. Routing must be explicit and auditable

**Full Plan**: agents/plans/local-ai-two-gpu-architecture.md (SUPERSEDED)

title: Provider/Model Architecture Overhaul
description:
Complete overhaul of local AI system architecture to properly separate providers from models, with intelligent concurrency control, health checking, and agent support.

## Goals
- Separate providers (hardware/services) from models (specific AI models)
- Intelligent routing with concurrency control (local GPUs: 1 req, cloud: 100 req)
- Agent-first design with OpenAI API compatibility for OpenCode integration
- Health checking with automatic failover (local ‚Üí cloud)
- Per-agent API keys and request prioritization
- Dashboard-only UI (sunset local-ai-app)

## Phases
- **Phase 1**: Critical Foundation (providers.yaml, ProviderManager, health checks, DB migrations)
- **Phase 2**: Agent Support (API keys, authentication, streaming, OpenCode integration)
- **Phase 3**: Dashboard Enhancement (image upload, provider visibility, UI improvements)
- **Phase 4**: Operational Excellence (metrics, cost tracking, monitoring, documentation)

## Key Decisions
- Hybrid concurrency: Try local GPUs ‚Üí queue/fail OR cloud fallback
- Agent priority (agent=0, user=1)
- OpenAI SDK compatibility (critical for OpenCode)
- Streaming required for agents and UI
- YAML-based provider config with health checking
- Persistent image storage for multimodal chat

## Documentation
- **Architecture Audit**: agents/reference/local-ai-architecture-audit.md
- **Architecture Plan**: agents/plans/local-ai-provider-model-architecture.md
- **Implementation Details**: agents/reference/local-ai-implementation-details.md

title: Deploy Chatterbox Turbo TTS service on Debian server
description:
Set up Chatterbox Turbo voice synthesis service on RTX 3070.

## Model Specification
- **Model**: Chatterbox Turbo (ResembleAI)
- **Parameters**: ~350M
- **VRAM**: Minimal (~1-2 GB)
- **Type**: Voice-cloning TTS
- **Co-hosted with**: Qwen3-Coder-7B on RTX 3070

## Service Architecture
FastAPI service exposing HTTP /tts endpoint:
- Accepts: text + reference audio clip
- Returns: audio/wav
- Model loaded once at startup

## Critical Constraints
- **Python 3.11 only** (PyTorch incompatible with 3.13)
- Requires HuggingFace authentication
- huggingface-hub>=0.23.2,<1.0 required

## Reference Audio Requirements
- Duration: 5-10 seconds
- Format: WAV, 16 kHz mono
- Content: Natural speech, single speaker

## Tasks
- [ ] Set up Python 3.11 virtualenv
- [ ] Install dependencies (torch, torchaudio, fastapi, chatterbox-tts)
- [ ] Configure HuggingFace authentication
- [ ] Create FastAPI TTS service
- [ ] Create/record reference audio clip
- [ ] Test TTS generation
- [ ] Containerize service (Docker)
- [ ] Integrate with router for agent responses

## Scheduling Rule
Serialize TTS after LLM inference - never run concurrently to avoid GPU contention.

**Parent Epic**: home-server-bme
